title: I’m Buying This Greenland Tariff Bitcoin Dump!

chunks.text:
All right, Trump tariffs. That's the reason why 
the market is red today. And if you're new here,   don't panic. This is a very standard 
Trump playbook. And within a week,   we'll definitely have our pump back because all 
these tariff announcements actually just follow   the exact same playbook. Today, I'm going 
to take you through the tariffs. I'm going   to take you through the playbook as to why this 
will recover and where we're at today. And then   we'll look at the chart structures and see 
whether this is a buy the dip opportunity or   whether this is a breakdown of this rally that 
we've had since the beginning of January. So,   that's what we're going to be doing 
today. I know it's a holiday in the US,   but here we are bringing you crypto love, 
cryptoism. Let's get the show on the road, guys. You know, to the people that are new here, this 
could actually be a bit scary. I won't lie to you,   but don't panic because this is normal. Every 
time we get this, it's the same Trump tariff   playbook. That's basically what's going on 
here. And that is to announce the tariffs on   a low liquidity weekend. And then you know, all 
the markets are closed. The only market that's   not closed is crypto. And crypto usually 
is the one that responds. This time it was   slightly different though because crypto didn't 
actually respond until the futures open. So,   we're going to talk about that and we're going to 
talk about why Trump even wants Greenland. Like,   why is Trump making a big story out of Greenland 
and why these tariffs are actually happening. So,   that's what we're going to be talking 
about today. Big, big, big show today. Guys, before we start the show today, I just 
want to give some love to BTCC because based   on our request, what they did was they introduced 
a 10% deposit bonus. So, how does a 10% deposit   bonus work? Basically, if you open an account on 
BTCC and it's a non-KYC exchange and you deposit   money into that account, whatever you deposit, you 
get a 10% deposit bonus. Now, here's the trick. You keep your money in the exchange. You play the 
deposit and then you withdraw your capital. Like   so simple. If you want to sign up for that, 
there's a link here in the description. These   are very short-term if you want. They bring them 
and they take them. So, if you have been thinking   of opening an account, just do it because it's 
basically free money. Anyway, let's carry on. Let's talk about the big story today. And 
guys, if you haven't liked this, please,   if you could like this video, it really helps 
me with distribution. Please, please, please,   if you could just smash the like button. I'm going 
to tell you guys exactly what's happening. So,   what is happening? Here's what's happening. The market closed on Friday and there was talk   about Greenland and the fact that Trump wanted to 
take over Greenland. And then over the weekend,   Trump published this article on Truth Social. He 
says we have subsidized Denmark and all of the   countries of the European Union and others for 
many years by not charging them tariffs or any   other form of remuneration. And he published 
this whole thing around how any country that   has sent troops to Greenland and is opposing 
the United States takeover of Greenland is   going to get an immediate tariff of 10% on any 
goods sent to the United States. On June 1st,   the tariff will be increased to 25% and the 
tariff will be in place until the transaction   has been completed for the total purchase 
of Greenland. So this tariff will be due   and payable until such time as the deal is reached 
for the complete and total purchase of Greenland. Now we got to talk about a lot of things here 
because number one, Trump's talking about tariffs   in a period where we don't even know if these 
tariffs are legal. Remember that the court has   been delaying a decision as to whether the Trump 
tariffs are actually legal. And right now there   is a 30% or 31% chance that the court rules in 
his favor. And here he is talking about tariffs   again. Now, interesting that he says to purchase 
a country. Did you know that you could purchase   a country? Cause I didn't know that. I got to 
be honest. Never knew that one country could   purchase another country. Where does the money 
go? If USA purchases Greenland, where does the   money go? Do the residents get it? Does the 
government get it? I'll show you all of that.

or Saturday, depending on where you were in   the world. This announcement was made and nothing 
happened to the market. So, nothing happened to   Bitcoin. Bitcoin remained at about 95,000. It 
was hovering around the $95,000 level whilst   this all happened until the futures opened. And 
when the futures opened, this is what happened:   gold and precious metals went up and Bitcoin and 
risk assets went down. So if you look at what   happened, Bitcoin went down. NASDAQ futures down 
1.5%. And if you look at gold went up and silver,   silver's absolutely parabolic. So gold is acting 
like Bitcoin. Silver is acting like an altcoin. It is a levered bet against Bitcoin and Bitcoin is 
acting like a risk asset and that's basically how   the market is pricing Bitcoin. What you can see 
is that right now the market is pricing Bitcoin   as a risk asset, not as a store of value asset 
because the hard money, the store of value assets,   the de-risking assets have become the commodities. And now that the commodities are on such a big   bull run, the market is basically treating 
Bitcoin like a technological risk-on asset. Now I made a whole video today. I recorded earlier 
today. Probably tomorrow it will be ready and I'll   drop it on Crypto Insider because I've broken down 
how this commodities super cycle links into the   crypto super cycle and where the opportunities 
are both in the commodities and in crypto. And   there are opportunities in both places. So let 
me talk about why I'm not worried about this. I think the first thing that we need to talk 
about is the first reason that I'm not worried   is if I look at the chart structure. Because I 
always go to the charts first now and I say look,   if I look at the chart structure, it is still 
very much in play. What I'm looking for from a   chart structure point of view is I'm looking 
for higher highs. There's a higher high and   I'm looking for higher lows and there are higher 
lows in both places. We haven't had a breakdown   of the chart structure yet. If we break below 90, 
then we may or it's actually not even below 90,   it's below 89,000. If we break below 89,000, then 
I would say that we've broken this structure and   then we need to watch out that we don't actually 
go somewhere below 84,000 or 85,000. But for now,   after a good start to the year, and as you 
can see, the daily RSIs went high almost   above or actually they touched above the 70 
RSI. You sometimes need a cool off because   RSIs remember go up and down kind of like 
this pattern over here. So you don't want   to go up in a straight line and right now 
the chart structure is very much intact. The second thing is I think the market is becoming 
desensitized to Trump tariffs. If you remember the   first time that Trump did tariffs, we had the 
massive drawdown. The second time slightly less   and then slightly less. And that's because the 
market seems to know Trump's playbook, right? The Trump playbook is a very simple playbook that 
The Kobeissi Letter actually published. And I want   to read you this playbook because then it'll kind 
of tell you when things are going to change. So   the tariff playbook: on Friday, President Trump 
posts a cryptic message signaling tariffs on a   specific country. Market drifts lower as there's 
uncertainty. Later that day or shortly after,   in this case Saturday, Trump announces a large new 
tariff. Number two, on Saturday and Sunday Trump   repeatedly doubles down on the tariff sending 
in this case Scott Bessent out there doing   interviews with reporters. Countries targeted 
by the new tariff respond publicly.

So the tariff playbook: on Friday, President Trump posts a cryptic message signaling tariffs on a specific country. Market drifts lower as there's uncertainty. Later that day or shortly after, in this case Saturday, Trump announces a large new tariff. Number two, on Saturday and Sunday Trump repeatedly doubles down on the tariff sending in this case Scott Bessent out there doing interviews with reporters. Countries targeted by the new tariff respond publicly. On Sunday   evening when the futures open the stock market 
drops because it's the initial emotional support   on the tariffs. On Monday and Tuesday, the 
president continues applying public pressure,   but investors begin to recognize that these 
tariffs are not live yet and still scheduled and   they'll take place at a later date. By Wednesday 
of the same week, dip buyers step in and we get   a rally. Problem is that rally usually sells 
off. And then on the following weekend, roughly   one week later, Trump posts that discussions 
are underway and that this is working towards   a solution with leaders of the country. This is 
the Trump trade on Sunday evening. That evening,   futures open sharply higher as optimism 
returns but gains fade into Monday cash   open. After Monday open, senior administrative 
officials such as Scott Bessent appear on live   television to reassure investors and talk about 
progress. Over the next two to four weeks,   various members of Trump administration 
continue to tease progress about a trade   agreement. Step 12. A trade deal is announced and 
the market hits new highs. Repeat from step one. This is exactly the same playbook. Exactly. On 
Friday, we had the cryptic message. On Saturday,   we got the tariff announcement. On Sunday, 
Scott Bessent came out and justified. I mean,   just listen to this here. Scott Bessent justifying 
why they need to buy Greenland. "President Trump   strongly believes that we cannot outsource 
our security because Kristen, let me tell you   what'll happen. And it might not be next year, 
might not be in five years, but down the road,   this fight for the Arctic is real. We would keep 
our NATO guarantees. And if there were an attack   on Greenland, from Russia, from some other 
area, we would get dragged in. So better now,   peace through strength, make it part of the United 
States." Scott Bessent is basically saying, look,   we need Greenland. And I'll talk to you in 
a second about why the USA needs Greenland. And so this is the reason why I'm not really 
that stressed. Also, Trump basically said,   look, it's any country that doesn't support our 
purchase or takeover of Greenland and any country   that actually sent in troops. So, I did a little 
bit of research as to like, wow, why would you   send in troops into Greenland, right? And this is 
the look, no jokes, this is the number of troops. France sent 15 soldiers. Finland sent two 
soldiers. Great Britain sent one soldier. Norway sent two soldiers. Germany 13 soldiers. There's more people in the Banter office than the   number of troops that these countries sent into 
Greenland. But I mean, I don't know if you've   ever taken time to see Greenland on a map. Guys, 
Greenland's huge. Like I didn't realize. You know   how big Greenland was? It's massive, bro. Like 
just look at it in context. It looks like it's   almost the size of Africa. Like that's how big 
Greenland is. But I think it's all ice and there's   not really much that you can actually do about it, 
or do with it. But that's what we'll talk about. Okay. So let's look at the next part of the 
playbook. The next part of the playbook is   that the European leaders come out over the 
weekend with threats and that's exactly what   happened. The US is set to halt approval on a 
trade deal because Trump threatened them with the   new tariffs. Then you also had the EU is preparing 
up to 93 billion in tariffs and other restrictions   on US companies in response to President Trump's 
10% pinpoint tariff. And France, Emmanuel Macron,   said President Macron's response to President 
Trump's new tariffs, "Europeans will respond in a   united and coordinated manner." And he also added, 
"No threat can influence us, neither in Greenland   nor in Ukraine." Shut up, bro.

your husband will beat you up. Sorry. So,   you know what I mean. Okay. So, basically, 
it's exactly the same playbook. It's the empty   threats. We will. No one's doing anything. You 
cannot operate without the United States. Stop   threatening the United States. Europe can't

Trump says. You know that. Everybody knows that. Stop threatening it. Just stop threatening because 
you sound stupid. That's basically what it is. Let's talk about why Trump wants this and how 
Trump's going to take it. So, first of all,   I was kind of surprised that they wanted to buy 
Greenland, but then I realized that it's not the   first time that the US actually bought things. The US actually did buy Alaska in 1867 for   $7.2 million. And there's been a couple of other 
times where they've actually bought countries. So,   you can actually buy countries. And when you 
buy a country, the money actually doesn't go   to the citizens. It goes to the government. And the government uses it for tax incentives,   to pay off debts, etc., and can make 
stimulus distributions to the residents. Be that as it may, I think the important 
thing is that there's no real war to   get Greenland. This is all about a 
peaceful takeover in a diplomatic way. And the reason why Trump wants it, well, 
the reason why Trump says he wants it is   because it's very strategic. And if you 
do look at where Greenland is on the map,   it is super strategic because it basically 
gives number one, it gives access to a whole   lot of different places in Europe because the 
Arctic Sea passes through it. And in fact,   David Sacks actually broke it down on the All-In 
Podcast, which I think is a pretty succinct   breakdown. "Why is Greenland so important? Well, 
it is becoming more significant from a national   security standpoint as those Arctic is melt and 
you have new shipping lanes that have opened   up. So, it is important on that dimension. But 
look, American politicians have wanted to acquire   Greenland for a long time. The great Secretary of 
State, William Seward, wanted to acquire it. He   acquired Alaska. He wanted to get Greenland too, 
was unable to make that deal. But FDR and Truman   both were interested in acquiring Greenland. It didn't work out obviously. So this is an old   idea that's new again thanks to President Trump. I think he makes a great point. Why does it belong   to the Danes? It's a small country in Europe. It's not part of North America. And I think   if we can acquire it for national security 
reasons and resource reasons, we should." And I think the odds, they're talking about 
this for national security reasons. I think   it's also for shipping reasons because if you look 
at shipping routes because the ice has started to   melt, this becomes a shipping route. You see, and 
that's why I think he wants it. Now, this wasn't   the case in the 2000s because you see the ice was 
there and then you couldn't go through. But now,   as the ice melts because of global warming, 
you can actually go through. So, it's very   strategic. And that's what Trump keeps saying. If 
we don't take Greenland, Russia or China will. And   I'm not letting that happen. If we don't take 
Greenland, Russia or China will take Greenland. And I am not going to let that happen. Is there 
any deal they can offer you? Either like, "Yeah,   sure. I'd love to make a deal with them. It's 
easier." But one way or the other, Trump says he's   basically taking Greenland and here he takes the 
mickey out of Denmark. Basically saying, "Look,   why do you own it and how can you protect us?

they say Denmark, but Denmark has spent no money. They have no military protection. They say that 
Denmark was there 300 years ago or something   with a boat. Well, we were there with boats,

a war against Russia, in a war against China. It   gives them an amazing position. Interestingly, the 
US actually does have some naval bases and some   military bases in there since 1951 because as part 
of their NATO defense, they have some bases there. There's another part of it and that's rare 
earth minerals. Now remember, China owns 90%   of the rare earth minerals, the processing of 
90% of the rare earth minerals. And one of the   things they did was when they threatened the 
US as a negotiating tactic, they limited the   export of rare earth minerals. Now that can wreck 
strategic industries like chip manufacturing,   like missiles, like weapons, etc. And Greenland 
is estimated to hold 36 million tons of rare earth   minerals. Only 1.5 million tons are considered 
proven. So there are minerals there. And China   is stepping up interests in Greenland because 
of the rare earth minerals. So, that could be   another one of the reasons why everybody is 
after this place. We don't really know why,   but you know, ultimately we're being fed 
one story. I think it's got much more to   do with the minerals and to keep the US 
close to Russia. If they ever needed to   get into some kind of war with Russia, the 
way to do it could be through Greenland. Let's talk about what the probabilities are here. So, the first thing is the Republicans are saying   if Trump invades Greenland, that would end 
his presidency. So it's not going to be an   invasion. It's going to be a peaceful takeover 
of Greenland. Even the Republicans are saying,   they've warned him, don't go and invade Greenland. Rather, let's just take it over peacefully. And I   kind of agree with that. There's a 13% chance that 
Trump's going to be impeached. So, he doesn't want   to get impeached. There's a 40% chance that the 
Greenland deal is signed by March 31st. That's   quite a big probability and it's on the increase, 
which means that they really believe.
